topic.title: Dates

body.p: Instances of class Date represent a specific day since the start of the Julian calendar. A Date may be understood as a less-precise version of a Timestamp. Thus, we can compare Date objects with instances of Timestamp. A Date is equivalent to a Timestamp of midnight on the same day.

topic.title: Create today’s date

body.p: datecreate todaySend a today message to the Date class. | date | date := Date today. ^date

topic.title: Create a date from a string

body.p: datecreate from stringdatecreate from streamSend a readFrom: message to Date with a ReadStream on a String containing the month, day, and year in any of several formats as shown. When the string uses a two-digit abbreviation for the year a Date is created for the current century today. To avoid any ambiguity create a Date using a four-digit year. | dates | dates := OrderedCollection new. dates add: (Date readFrom: 'January 31, 1994' readStream); add: (Date readFrom: '31 January 1994' readStream); add: (Date readFrom: '1/31/1994' readStream); add: (Date readFrom: '1.31.1994' readStream); add: (Date readFrom: '1-31-1994' readStream). ^dates
As an alternative, send a readFromString: message, as defined in Object.

topic.title: Create a date from a day, month, and year

body.p: datecreate from month day yearSend a newDay:monthNumber:year: message to the Date class. The newDay argument is the day number. The monthNumber argument is the month number. The year argument is the year, with or without the century part. If a two-digit year is provided then it is applied to the current century today. Use a four-digit year to avoid ambiguity. | date1 | date1 := Date newDay: 31 monthNumber: 1 year: 1994.

To specify the month by name, send a newDay:month:year: message to Date, with the month argument as the unique first letters of a month name expressed as a Symbol. | date2 | date2 := Date newDay: 31 month: #Jan year: 1994.

topic.title: Create a date by days since January 1

body.p: datecreate from day in yearDuring a series of date computations that span several months in the same year, it can be helpful to treat a date as the number of days that it represents since the beginning of the year. After the computation is completed, you can convert the day-count back into a date.

Send a newDay:year: message to Date. The first argument is the number of days from the beginning of the year. The second argument is the year number. | date | date := Date newDay: 32 year: 1994. ^date

topic.title: Date relative to 1901

body.p: datecreate from days since beginning of timeDuring a series of date computations that span multiple years, it can be helpful to treat a date as the number of days that it represents since January 1, 1901 (the beginning of time in ∏). After the computation is completed, you can convert the day-count back into a date.
Send a fromDays: message to Date. The argument is the number of days from the beginning of 1901. | date | date := Date fromDays: (94 * 366). ^date
Send an asDays message to a date to get the number of days since January 1, 1901: | date | date := Date today. ^date asDays
Send an asSeconds message to a date for the number of seconds since January 1, 1901: | date | date := Date today. ^date asSeconds

topic.title: Get the day of the week

body.p: dateget day of weekSend a weekday message to a date. The name of the week day is expressed as a Symbol, such as #Friday. | date | date := Date today. ^date weekday

topic.title: Get the day of the month

body.p: dateget day of monthSend a dayOfMonth message to a date. The day number within the month is returned. | date | date := Date today. ^date dayOfMonth

topic.title: Get the day of the year

body.p: dateget day of yearSend a day message to a date. The day number within the year is returned. | date | date := Date today. ^date day

topic.title: Get the name of the month

body.p: dateget month nameSend a monthName message to a date. The month name is expressed as a Symbol, as in #January. | date | date := Date today. ^date monthName

topic.title: Get the number of the month

body.p: dateget month numberSend a monthIndex message to a date. | date | date := Date today. ^date monthIndex

topic.title: Count the days in the month

body.p: dateget days in monthSend a daysInMonth message to a date. | date | date := Date today. ^date daysInMonth

topic.title: Get the year number from a date

body.p: dateget yearSend a year message to a date. | date | date := Date today. ^date year

topic.title: Count the days in a year

body.p: dateget days in yearSend a daysInYear message to a date. | date | date := Date today. ^date daysInYear

topic.title: Count the days remaining in the year

body.p: dateget days remaining in yearSend a daysLeftInYear message to a date. | date | date := Date today. ^date daysLeftInYear

topic.title: Test for leap year

body.p: datetest for leap yearSend a leap message to a date. The result is 1 in a leap year and zero otherwise. | date | date := Date today. ^date leap

topic.title: Add/subtract days to a date

body.p: dateadd days to dateSend an addDays: message to a date. The argument is the number of days to be added, and can be a negative number. | date daysToAdd | date := Date today. daysToAdd := 60. ^date addDays: daysToAdd

datesubtract days from dateSend a subtractDays: message to a date. The argument is the number of days to be subtracted, and it can be a negative number. | date daysToSubtract | date := Date today. daysToSubtract := 60. ^date subtractDays: daysToSubtract

topic.title: Get the number of days between two dates

body.p: dateget difference between datesSend a subtractDate: message to a date. The argument is the date to be subtracted, which can be either before or after the first date. | date1 date2 | date1 := Date today. date2 := Date readFrom: '31 December 1999'. ^date2 subtractDate: date1

topic.title: Get a previous day of the week

body.p: dateget previous daySend a previous: message to a date. The argument is the name of the preceding weekday whose date you desire, expressed as a Symbol. | date dayOfWeek | date := Date today. dayOfWeek := #Monday. ^date previous: dayOfWeek

topic.title: Test/compare dates

body.p: datecompare datesDates respond to many of the same test methods as numbers. Return values are booleans. date1 = date2. "equality" date1 ~= date2. "non-equality" date1 < date2. "earlier than" date1 <= date2. "earlier or equal" date1 > date2. "later than" date1 >= date2. "later or equal"

topic.title: Format a Date

body.p:
A date can be formatted by specifying an array of format arguments sent with the printFormat: message. The six elements are:
Day’s position in the string (1, 2, or 3)
Month’s position in the string (1, 2, or 3)
Year’s position in the string (1, 2, or 3)
The separator character
Month’s format: 1 (numeric), 2 (abbreviation), or 3 (full name)
Year’s format: 1 (with century) or 2 (without century)
Send a printFormat: message to the date. The argument is an array of six elements. | date | date := Date today. ^date printFormat: #(2 1 3 $- 3 1)
